meanings.definition: To irritate or provoke to a high degree
meanings.sent1: The constant noise from the construction site began to exasperate the residents.
meanings.sent2: Her constant interruptions during the meeting started to exasperate her colleagues.
meanings.sent3: Trying to untangle the knot in the necklace only served to exasperate her further.
meanings.sent4: The never-ending traffic jam seemed to exasperate time itself.
meanings.sent5: The stubborn screw refused to budge, continuing to exasperate the handyman.

meanings.sent1: The slow internet speed can exasperate users trying to stream videos.
meanings.sent2: Waiting in long lines at the grocery store can exasperate shoppers.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous puppy's antics never failed to exasperate the older dog.
meanings.sent4: The constant rain began to exasperate the farmers trying to harvest their crops.
meanings.sent5: The repeated technical issues with the computer started to exasperate the IT specialist.

meanings.definition: To make someone very angry or impatient
meanings.sent1: His constant lateness would always exasperate his punctual friend.
meanings.sent2: The never-ending paperwork on her desk began to exasperate the office manager.
meanings.sent3: The toddler's refusal to eat anything but cookies exasperated his parents.
meanings.sent4: The unanswered phone calls continued to exasperate the worried family.
meanings.sent5: The repeated mistakes in the report started to exasperate the meticulous editor.
